description: This course is an introductory graduate course on computer architecture with an emphasis on a quantitative approach to cost/performance design tradeoffs. The course covers the fundamentals of classical and modern uniprocessor design: performance and cost issues, instruction sets, pipelining, superscalar, out-of-order, and speculative execution mechanisms, caches, physical memory, virtual memory, and I/O. Other topics include: static scheduling, VLIW and EPIC, software speculation, long (SIMD) and short (multimedia) vector execution, multithreading, and an introduction to shared memory multiprocessors.
name: COMPUTER ARCHITECTURE

values.comments:
This course is an introductory graduate course on computer architecture with an emphasis on a quantitative approach to cost/performance design tradeoffs. The course covers the fundamentals of classical and modern uniprocessor design: performance and cost issues, instruction sets, pipelining, superscalar, out-of-order, and speculative execution mechanisms, caches, physical memory, virtual memory, and I/O. Other topics include: static scheduling, VLIW and EPIC, software speculation, long (SIMD) and short (multimedia) vector execution, multithreading, and an introduction to shared memory multiprocessors.

Students generally praised the course as “excellent” and “useful.” Most felt that that the assignments complemented the lecture content well. However, many students pointed out the course was disorganized, as assignments and projects were dropped.

Students had mixed reviews for Professor Martin. Some students found him to be caring and easy to talk to. However, others felt that his attitude was rude and that his lectures were slow-paced and relied too much on PowerPoint.

Students generally found the workload to be great. Knowledge of computer organization and basic programming skills are required for this course.

Students generally praised the course as “excellent” and “useful.” Most felt that that the assignments complemented the lecture content well. However, many students pointed out the course was disorganized, as assignments and projects were dropped.
